ratings.comment: I was failing this class because I hate this subject so much, but it's a requirement for my major.  I called him with my concerns, and not only did he stay on the phone with me for 16 minutes, but he offered lots of help and allayed my fears.  He's a great guy in my book.  He really wants his students to do well.
Dude likes to talk. A lot. He's OK, but not very engaging and gives exams the same day he needs to finish up his lectures. Avoid this class if you can, especially since it's only once a week.

very boring lectures, especially if you take the seminar one like i did. the fact is that he thinks you are way more knowlegable about mayan glyphs than you are for an intro class, and for being a one twenty the work load was intense. however, he does let you re do homework and is good about helping you and emails. id say weekly homework is 4 hrs
Boring lecturer yes, but this man is still passionate about the material and a really kind prof.  He is there for his students, and is super chill.
Great Proffesor. Keeps you interested and from falling asleep. His lecture notes were already online, so all you had to do was sit back and enjoy the story. Exam was a little tough though.

He's a solid professor. He likes to talk and is more into the archeological aspect of the topic. In my opinion, this led to him getting off topic and focusing on things I didn't feel were as important to the subject. Tests are pretty standard - Identification, Short Response, and Essay. You're supposed to read the book, but class seemed like enough

I developed a great dislike for this man's teaching methods. Boring, repetitive minus the usefulness. I liked the topic but he made me not want to go to class. We talked about beads for an entire lecture for no reason. The essay was pointless, as the final exam had pretty much the same question on it. The readings are pointless to attempt.
hated this class.  he's way boring, even for me (an anthro major).  the person who graded the exams was way too tough.  i wish i wasn't required to take this class.  it was a waste of my tuition.
Fantastic Prof!  Study from the slides! Memorize the slides and you'll do fine on the exams.

Had three different professors for this class, Yaeger was easily the most interesting, personable, and more importantly, the best teacher.  The class in itself I wouldn't recommend to anyone, but if I HAD to take an Anthropology class again, I would probably try to take it with him.

Monotone lecturer...says "ummm" a lot. I got a lot more out of the online readings than the lectures. Exam was easy as long as you know everything on the study guide he provides before the midterm...I skipped class a lot and still did really well on the exam.

322 is a very information oriented class. He only has one grader to grade 75+ exams, and basically provides her with a list of concepts and phrases. She then goes through the exams and looks for these exact phrases (she underlines them). So if you don't write them down, chances are you won't do very well. So pay attention in lecture.

Extremely interesting topic... but kind of a monotonous lecturer. Used the textbook only as supplementary to lecture... so don't read all 1000 pages! Simple paper (ex: Why is "Apocalypto" awful?), 3 tests which were intimidating but covered all in lecture! Take if interested in the topic, can be boring but a simple AB at least if you work.

boring, boring, boring.  Probably fell asleep half the time.  Monotone voice, rambles on.  You'd think he would talk about the culture of the maya people right? no, he spent way too much time talking about each site and every single building that made up said site.  who cares about buildings? tell me about the maya people.  don't fall asleep.

He's a nice guy, but he has a Grad student grade our tests, and she is a REALLY hard grader. I read through all the material for all the exams, attended every lecture, studied my patutie off, and ended up with a B.

Really fascinating class. At first it seems really dull but once he gets past theory and into talking about civilizations it's pretty interesting. Though beware there is lots of material and you basically need to know it all for the exams. Oh, pick and choose the readings there are way too many...don't buy the course pack either, it's like $90.
soooo bad. dont take his class if you can avoid it.
Notes online is a plus.  Always study from the book's URL.
No Comments

I took the class looking for something interesting and out of interest for anthropology and archaeology, but found myself very disappointed.  He's a nice guy and is passionate about his subject, but the class was extremely boring and bothered me because I felt like I was doing busy work all the time.  It convinced me not to major in anthropology.

I would not suggest taking this if you want excitment or are intrested in Antrho. The lectures are dry and he often gets off topic. He also doesn't seem to teach a whole lot even for an intoro course. On the plus side it's not a hard class and when I took it there was no work due (or tests) in Dec.

All he did was read from his powerpoint slides, and it wasn't anything you could already find IN THE BOOK anyway. The lecture should extend the readings, not summarize them. PPT is useless as a lecture summary; if the lecture is written out in bullet points, why do you need a lecturer? YOU DON'T.
He's a cool dude.
Very good professor, I will take his classes again. Only 1 test no final, easy lectures, definitly good!
He teaches to fast.... hard to understand, to many slides.....
This was an awesome class and Yaeger really knew what he was talking about as he just got back from belize before the semester started.
